DataElement.preferredDefinition: The class of DNA testing used to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder.:A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a specific disease or disorder.

Concepts.definition: The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder.

Property.preferredDefinition: Scientific or clinical procedures and methods.

Concepts.definition: A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.

DataElementConcept.administrativeNotes: 3/22/23 Created per PCDC metadata template. mr

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The process of isolating and testing the DNA of an embryo or a person to detect the presence of genetic alterations or defects that may predispose to the future development of a disease or disorder._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function._A technique used to identify the sequence of individual nucleobases in a single strand of DNA fragment template, which can be a plasmid insert, genomic DNA or a PCR product. In addition, direct sequencing of genomic DNA or PCR products does not require sub-cloning of the gene of interest into a vector.

Concepts.definition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.
A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

A technique used to identify the sequence of individual nucleobases in a single strand of DNA fragment template, which can be a plasmid insert, genomic DNA or a PCR product. In addition, direct sequencing of genomic DNA or PCR products does not require sub-cloning of the gene of interest into a vector.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function._A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

Concepts.definition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.
A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.
A long linear double-stranded polymer formed from nucleotides attached to a deoxyribose backbone and found in the nucleus of a cell; associated with the transmission of genetic information.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Dideoxy Chain Termination DNA Sequencing Capillary Electrophoresis
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A DNA sequencing technique in which a mixture of deoxynucleosidetriphosphates (dNTPs) and chain-terminating dNTPs, which are radioactively or fluorescently labeled, are combined within the reaction mixture. Once the reaction is complete, the DNA strands are separated by size, and the labeled chain terminating dNTPs can be read in sequence by the investigator or by a machine._An electrophoresis procedure, in which a sample is introduced into a capillary tube and the components are separated by the application of high voltage. Due to the large surface to volume ratio, cooling is more efficient, allowing use of higher voltages.  As a result, separation occurs more quickly and sensitivity is increased. The technique allows for separation of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates.

Concepts.definition: A DNA sequencing technique in which a mixture of deoxynucleosidetriphosphates (dNTPs) and chain-terminating dNTPs, which are radioactively or fluorescently labeled, are combined within the reaction mixture. Once the reaction is complete, the DNA strands are separated by size, and the labeled chain terminating dNTPs can be read in sequence by the investigator or by a machine.

An electrophoresis procedure, in which a sample is introduced into a capillary tube and the components are separated by the application of high voltage. Due to the large surface to volume ratio, cooling is more efficient, allowing use of higher voltages.  As a result, separation occurs more quickly and sensitivity is increased. The technique allows for separation of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Dideoxy Chain Termination DNA Sequencing Gel Electrophoresis
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A DNA sequencing technique in which a mixture of deoxynucleosidetriphosphates (dNTPs) and chain-terminating dNTPs, which are radioactively or fluorescently labeled, are combined within the reaction mixture. Once the reaction is complete, the DNA strands are separated by size, and the labeled chain terminating dNTPs can be read in sequence by the investigator or by a machine._Gel electrophoresis is a method of separating large molecules (such as DNA fragments or proteins) from a mixture of similar molecules by electrophoretic filtration through a gelatinous matrix.  Subject to an electric field, each molecule in the sample mixture migrates through the matrix at a different rate, depending mainly on electrical charge and size, resulting in spatial separation within the matrix of each molecular species in the sample mixture.  Agarose and acrylamide in a cylindrical tube or slab gel are commonly used media for electrophoresis of proteins and nucleic acids.

Concepts.definition: A DNA sequencing technique in which a mixture of deoxynucleosidetriphosphates (dNTPs) and chain-terminating dNTPs, which are radioactively or fluorescently labeled, are combined within the reaction mixture. Once the reaction is complete, the DNA strands are separated by size, and the labeled chain terminating dNTPs can be read in sequence by the investigator or by a machine.

Gel electrophoresis is a method of separating large molecules (such as DNA fragments or proteins) from a mixture of similar molecules by electrophoretic filtration through a gelatinous matrix.  Subject to an electric field, each molecule in the sample mixture migrates through the matrix at a different rate, depending mainly on electrical charge and size, resulting in spatial separation within the matrix of each molecular species in the sample mixture.  Agarose and acrylamide in a cylindrical tube or slab gel are commonly used media for electrophoresis of proteins and nucleic acids.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Multi-gene Panel Sequencing Less Than Five Genes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest._A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest is smaller than another object in quantity or measure or value or status._A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

Concepts.definition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest.
A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest is smaller than another object in quantity or measure or value or status.
A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one.
A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Multi-gene Panel Sequencing Greater Than Fifty Genes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest._A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status._A natural number greater than forty-nine and less than fifty-one and the quantity that it denotes._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

Concepts.definition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest.
A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that an object of interest exceeds another object in quantity or measure or value or status.
A natural number greater than forty-nine and less than fifty-one and the quantity that it denotes.
A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Multi-gene Panel Sequencing Twenty One To Fifty Genes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest._A natural number greater than twenty and less than twenty-two and the quantity that it denotes._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._A natural number greater than forty-nine and less than fifty-one and the quantity that it denotes._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

Concepts.definition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest.
A natural number greater than twenty and less than twenty-two and the quantity that it denotes.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
A natural number greater than forty-nine and less than fifty-one and the quantity that it denotes.
A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Multi-gene Panel Sequencing Five To Twenty Genes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest._A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._A natural number greater than nineteen and less than twenty-one and the quantity that it denotes._A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

Concepts.definition: An application of next-generation targeted sequencing where the sequencing primers are designed to specifically target a panel of multiple genes or loci of interest.
A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
A natural number greater than nineteen and less than twenty-one and the quantity that it denotes.
A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position on a particular chromosome and serves as the template for a product that contributes to a phenotype or a biological function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that can determine the nucleotide sequence for all of the RNA transcripts in an individual.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that can determine the nucleotide sequence for all of the RNA transcripts in an individual.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of a high-throughput microarray where all of the known CpG islands either in a single specimen or all of the known promoter sequences of a specimen or a population group are coupled to beads or microwells to determine which are methylated.

Concepts.definition: The use of a high-throughput microarray where all of the known CpG islands either in a single specimen or all of the known promoter sequences of a specimen or a population group are coupled to beads or microwells to determine which are methylated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.

Concepts.definition: A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The assessment of the chromosomal morphology and number in somatic cells of an individual.

Concepts.definition: The chromosomal morphology and number in somatic cells of an individual.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The attachment of a methyl group to a molecule. Usually refers to DNA methylation. The expression level of a gene is often regulated by its methylation state; expressed genes are usually hypomethylated. C0025723: Methylation

Concepts.definition: The covalent chemical or biochemical addition of a methyl group(s) to a compound. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: RT-PCR is short for reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction. It is a technique in which an RNA strand is first transcribed into a DNA complement and then subjected to PCR amplification. Transcribing an RNA strand into a DNA complement is termed reverse transcription and is done by the enzyme reverse transcriptase. (from Wikipedia)

Concepts.definition: A laboratory procedure in which an RNA strand is first transcribed into a DNA complement and then subjected to PCR amplification. Transcribing an RNA strand into a DNA complement is termed reverse transcription and is done by the enzyme reverse transcriptase.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Technologies that facilitate the rapid determination of the DNA sequence of large numbers of strands or segments of DNA.

Concepts.definition: Technologies that facilitate the rapid determination of the nucleotide sequence of large numbers of strands or segments of DNA or RNA.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that can determine the DNA sequence for all of the exons in an individual.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that can determine the DNA sequence for all of the exons in an individual.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that can determine the DNA sequence for nearly the entire genome of an individual.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that can determine the DNA sequence for nearly the entire genome of an individual.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genomic microarray-based method able to detect single nucleotide polymorphisms.

Concepts.definition: A genomic microarray-based method able to detect single nucleotide polymorphisms.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.2.1 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0001995. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not provided or available.

Concepts.definition: Not provided or available.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 10/10/23 changed Long Name from "Not Stated" to match NCIt Preferred name and current caDSR concept Long Name of "Not Reported" per Brenda.Janice . LS

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A DNA sequencing technique in which selected regions of an individual's genome are sequenced.

Concepts.definition: A DNA sequencing technique in which selected regions of an individual's genome are sequenced.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of whole transcriptome shotgun sequencing technique in which select portions of the transcriptome are selected for sequencing.

Concepts.definition: A type of whole transcriptome shotgun sequencing technique in which select portions of the transcriptome are selected for sequencing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A molecular cytogenetic method combining chromosomal comparative genomic hybridization technique and microarray to detect chromosomal aberrations and changes in DNA copy numbers in the genome, using oligonucleotides immobilized on a solid support as targets for hybridization.

Concepts.definition: A molecular cytogenetic method combining chromosomal comparative genomic hybridization technique and microarray to detect chromosomal aberrations and changes in DNA copy numbers in the genome, using oligonucleotides immobilized on a solid support as targets for hybridization.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary molecular analysis system for single molecule detection with no amplification. It uses unique fluorescent barcodes for direct, digital detection and copy number quantitation of hundreds (â‰¤800) of different target molecules in a single run. It requires only nanoscale amounts of RNA and has a detection sensitivity down to 1 copy per cell.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary molecular analysis system for single molecule detection with no amplification. It uses unique fluorescent barcodes for direct, digital detection and copy number quantitation of hundreds (<=800) of different target molecules in a single run. It requires only nanoscale amounts of RNA and has a detection sensitivity down to 1 copy per cell.

In addition, direct sequencing of genomic DNA or PCR products does not require sub-cloning of the gene of interest into a vector.
